column2: For two days before Mme. de Dey had not been at home to her visitors, and on the previous evening her door had been shut, on the ground of indisposition. Two such events at any ordinary time would have produced in Carentan the same sensation that Paris knows on nights when there is no performance at the theaters--existence is in some sort incomplete; but in those times when the least indiscretion on the part of an aristocrat might be a matter of life and death, this conduct of Mme. de Dey's was likely to bring about the most disastrous consequences for her.

column3: A battalion is coming here to night.

column2: And he went.

column2: The Countess's need to believe in the faith of her sometime attorney was so great, that she dared not entertain any suspicion of him.
column3: The Countess's need to believe in the faith of her sometime attorney was so great, that she dared not entertain any suspicion of him.

column2: She fled upstairs; she felt scarcely strength enough to stand; she opened the door, and sprang, half dead with fear, into her son's arms.
column3: She fled upstairs; she felt scarcely strength enough to stand; she opened the door, and sprang, half dead with fear, into her son's arms.

column2: Oh! my child! my child! she sobbed, covering him with almost frenzied kisses.
column3: Oh! my child! my child! she sobbed, covering him with almost frenzied kisses.

column2: Madame!... said a stranger's voice.
column3: Madame!... said a stranger's voice.

column2: Oh! it is not he! she cried, shrinking away in terror, and she stood face to face with the conscript, gazing at him with haggard eyes.
column3: Oh! it is not he! she cried, shrinking away in terror, and she stood face to face with the conscript, gazing at him with haggard eyes.

column2: _O saint bon Dieu!_ how like he is! cried Brigitte.
column3: underscore O saint bon Dieu!underscore how like he is! cried Brigitte.

column2: There was silence for a moment; even the stranger trembled at the sight of Mme. de Dey's face.
column3: There was silence for a moment; even the stranger trembled at the sight of Mme. de Dey's face.

column2: Ah! monsieur, she said, leaning on the arm of Brigitte's husband, feeling for the first time the full extent of a sorrow that had all but killed her at its first threatening; "ah! monsieur, I cannot stay to see you any longer ... permit my servants to supply my place, and to see that you have all that you want."

column2: She went down to her own room, Brigitte and the old serving-man half carrying her between them.
column3: She went down to her own room, Brigitte and the old serving man half carrying her between them.

column2: The housekeeper set her mistress in a chair, and broke out:

column2: Brigitte! cried Mme. de Dey.
column3: Brigitte! cried Mme. de Dey.

column2: Brigitte said no more.

column2: Hold your tongue, chatterbox, said her husband, in a low voice; "do you want to kill madame?"
column3: Hold your tongue, chatterbox, said her husband, in a low voice; "do you want to kill madame?"

column2: A sound came from the conscript's room as he drew his chair to the table.
column3: A sound came from the conscript's room as he drew his chair to the table.

column2: I shall not stay here, cried Mme. de Dey; "I shall go into the conservatory; I shall hear better there if anyone passes in the night."
column3: I shall not stay here, cried Mme. de Dey; "I shall go into the conservatory; I shall hear better there if anyone passes in the night."

column2: She still wavered between the fear that she had lost her son and the hope of seeing him once more.
column3: She still wavered between the fear that she had lost her son and the hope of seeing him once more.

column2: That night was hideously silent.
column3: That night was hideously silent.

column2: Once, for the Countess, there was an awful interval, when the battalion of conscripts entered the town, and the men went by, one by one, to their lodgings.
column3: Once, for the Countess, there was an awful interval, when the battalion of conscripts entered the town, and the men went by, one by one, to their lodgings.

column2: Every footfall, every sound in the street, raised hopes to be disappointed; but it was not for long, the dreadful quiet succeeded again.
column3: Every footfall, every sound in the street, raised hopes to be disappointed; but it was not for long, the dreadful quiet succeeded again.

column2: Toward morning the Countess was forced to return to her room. Brigitte, ever keeping watch over her mistress's movements, did not see her come out again; and when she went, she found the Countess lying there dead.
column3: Toward morning the Countess was forced to return to her room. Brigitte, ever keeping watch over her mistress's movements, did not see her come out again; and when she went, she found the Countess lying there dead.

column2: I expect she heard that conscript, cried Brigitte, "walking about Monsieur Auguste's room, whistling that accursed _Marseillaise_ of theirs while he dressed, as if he had been in a stable!
column3: I expect she heard that conscript, cried Brigitte, "walking about Monsieur Auguste's room, whistling that accursed underscore Marseillaise underscore of theirs while he dressed, as if he had been in a stable!

column2: That must have killed her."

column2: But it was a deeper and a more solemn emotion, and doubtless some dreadful vision, that had caused Mme. de Dey's death; for at the very hour when she died at Carentan, her son was shot in le Morbihan.
column3: But it was a deeper and a more solemn emotion, and doubtless some dreadful vision, that had caused Mme. de Dey's death; for at the very hour when she died at Carentan, her son was shot in le Morbihan.

column2: This tragical story may be added to all the instances on record of the workings of sympathies uncontrolled by the laws of time and space. These observations, collected with scientific curiosity by a few isolated individuals, will one day serve as documents on which to base the foundations of a new science which hitherto has lacked its man of genius.
